title: Ice Cream Bar at the Hotel Pool
question_text:
A large hotel has just installed an ice cream bar at its pool and would like to gauge its success by conducting a survey. The hotel manager randomly selects $3$ of the $32\text{ floors}$ of the hotel and surveys all the residents on those $3\text{ floors}$.
The design of this survey is best described as a
solution:
A cluster sample is a sampling method that divides samples into random groups (in this case: floors) and then measures all of the samples within a group.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' - The survey would be a simple random sample if the rooms were randomly chosen out of all the rooms in the hotel.

Choice 'B' - The survey would be stratified if the hotel rooms were sorted on some characteristic (for example, rooms occupied by families with children and rooms occupied by adults only) and then a random sample was taken from each group.

Choices 'D' and 'E' - Blocking and matched pair are terms used only in the design of experiments, not surveys.
